bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Emilie Lawrence Reed, January 17, 1924

div1.p: Kean informs Emilie Lawrence Reed that his son Robert is graduating from MIT in chemistry. He discusses the role of Sternberg and Gorgas with the Yellow Fever Commission.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Emilie Lawrence Reed, January 17, 1924
div1.p:
I am glad to get your
card and have news of you
and to see what a comfort-
able house Blossom has-

I wish I had a house like
that to spend my declining
years in when I retire which
will be in June next-

I was interested to see the report
of physical examination of
your son Lawrence come over
my desk today and to see
that his health is fine - also
that he begins to need glasses
for age!

Well I have never seen my
review of the 3rd Edition of
Dr Kellys “Walter Reed and
Yellow Fever” in print- Perhaps
they did not like it.- I
made it clear that neither
Sternberg nor Gorgas helped
the work of the Yellow Fever
Commission in any way &
made an effective contrast
between what was done for
Gorgas & for Reed-

I will write and ask the
publishers what they did
with the review-

We are all well- Bob finished
at Mass Institute of Technology
in June & gone out to sup-
port himself as a chemist
I am rather lame but still
like Johnny Walker going
strong - Give my love to
Blossom & remember me to
the doctor.
